fr:link.title: A leisurely introduction to simplicial sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The abstract simplex \Delta (also called the simplex category), is the category whose objects are the non-negative integers, thought of as finite ordinals, and whose morphisms are the non-decreasing functions between them.

fr:title.text: A leisurely introduction to simplicial sets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A leisurely introduction to simplicial sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Simplicial sets are introduced in a way that should be pleasing to the formally-inclined. Care is taken to provide both the geometric intuition and the categorical details, laying a solid foundation for the reader to move on to more advanced topological or higher categorical applications. The highlight, and the only possibly non-standard content, is a unified presentation of every adjunction whose left adjoint has the category of simplicial sets as its domain: geometric realization and the total singular complex functor, the ordinary nerve and its left adjoint, the homotopy coherent nerve and its left adjoint, and subdivision and extension are some of the many examples that fit within this framework.

fr:link.title: A leisurely introduction to simplicial sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The abstract simplex \Delta (also called the simplex category), is the category whose objects are the non-negative integers, thought of as finite ordinals, and whose morphisms are the non-decreasing functions between them.

fr:link.title: A leisurely introduction to simplicial sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The simplex category is generated by the coface maps d^i: n\hookrightarrow n+1 which miss i, and the codegeneracy maps s^i: n+1\twoheadrightarrow n which repeat i. (By convention, we drop the dependence of d^i and s^i on n.) In particular, it is presented by maps of these types satisfying five simplicial identities.

fr:link.title: A leisurely introduction to simplicial sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A simplicial set is a presheaf on the abstract simplex. The category of simplicial sets sSet is the category of presheaves on the abstract simplex.

fr:link.title: A leisurely introduction to simplicial sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: By the presentation of the abstract simplex, a simplicial set consists of a sequence of sets X_n for each nonnegative integer n, together with face maps X_n\xrightarrow {d_i} X_{n-1} and degeneracy maps X_n\xrightarrow {s_i} X_{n+1}.

We interpret the elements of X_n as n-simplices. The face map d_i identifies the i-th face of the simplex, which by convention is the face not containing the i-th vertex. The degeneracy map s_i interprets each n-simplex as a degenerate n+1-simplex, with the ith vertex repeated.
Let X be a simplicial set. A simplex x\in X_n is degenerate if it is in the image of one of the degeneracy maps s^i.

fr:link.title: A leisurely introduction to simplicial sets

fr:title.text: The universal property of the standard simplex

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The universal property of the standard simplex

fr:link.title: A leisurely introduction to simplicial sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: By the Yoneda lemma, there is a natural isomorphism \operatorname {Hom}(\Delta ^n, X)\cong X_n, where \Delta ^n is the standard n-simplex and X is any simplicial set. In other words, the n-simplices of X are exactly the simplex maps from \Delta ^n to X.

fr:link.title: A leisurely introduction to simplicial sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: By the density formula, a simplicial set X is the colimit of each of its standard simplices. As such, each simplicial set is "glued together" from standard simplicies in a canonical way.

fr:link.title: A leisurely introduction to simplicial sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Delta \xrightarrow {F} E be any functor, where E is cocomplete and locally small. Because the simplex category is small, the left Kan extension L of F along the Yoneda embedding into simplicial sets exists and is computed by the colimit formula. Moreover, this functor is left adjoint to the functor E\xrightarrow {R} sSet acting by x\mapsto n\mapsto E(Fn, x):

fr:title.text: Geometric realization of a simplicial set

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Geometric realization of a simplicial set

fr:title.text: Geometric realization of a simplicial set

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Geometric realization of a simplicial set

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Delta \to Top send n to the topological n-simplex \{x_0,x_1,\dots ,x_n\in \mathbb {R}: x_0+\dots +x_1 = 0, x_i\geq 0\}. Then the geometric realization of a simplicial set is the Kan extension of this functor to sSet.

The singular simplicial complex functor from spaces to simplicial sets is the right adjoint to the geometric realization functor. By abstract nonsense, this is given by \operatorname {Sing}(X)_n = \operatorname {Top}(|\Delta ^n|, X).

fr:link.title: A leisurely introduction to simplicial sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Delta \xrightarrow {F} Cat send n in the abstract simplex to the ordinal category n. Then the nerve functor N is the right adjoint to the Kan extension of F to the category of simplicial sets. In particular, as n-simplices, FC has functors Fn\to C.

More concretely, let C be a small category. The nerve of C is the simplicial set whose n-simplicies are n-long strings of composable maps in C. The degeneracy map s_i takes a string of length n and inserts an identity at position i, while the face map d_i composes the ith and i+1st arrows (or else leaves out the first or last arrow, if i=0 or i=n.)

fr:link.title: A leisurely introduction to simplicial sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The simplicial n-sphere \partial \Delta ^n is the simplicial set consisting of the boundary of the standard n-simplex, i.e. \partial \Delta ^n = \bigcup _i d_i(\Delta ^n).
An n-sphere in a simplicial set X is a map \Lambda _k^n\to X.

fr:link.title: A leisurely introduction to simplicial sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The simplicial horn \Lambda _k^n is the simplicial set consisting of all faces of the [standard n-simplex] except for the ith, i.e. \Lambda _k^n = \bigcup _{i\neq k} d_i(\Delta ^n).
A horn in a simplicial set X is a map \Lambda _k^n\to X.
A simplicial horn \Lambda _k^n is an inner horn if 0 < k < n and an outer horn otherwise.

fr:link.title: A leisurely introduction to simplicial sets

fr:title.text: Geometric realization of a simplicial set

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Geometric realization of a simplicial set

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Delta \to Top send n to the topological n-simplex \{x_0,x_1,\dots ,x_n\in \mathbb {R}: x_0+\dots +x_1 = 0, x_i\geq 0\}. Then the geometric realization of a simplicial set is the Kan extension of this functor to sSet.

fr:link.title: A leisurely introduction to simplicial sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Delta \xrightarrow {F} E be any functor, where E is cocomplete and locally small. Because the simplex category is small, the left Kan extension L of F along the Yoneda embedding into simplicial sets exists and is computed by the colimit formula. Moreover, this functor is left adjoint to the functor E\xrightarrow {R} sSet acting by x\mapsto n\mapsto E(Fn, x):

fr:link.title: A leisurely introduction to simplicial sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Delta \xrightarrow {F} Cat send n in the abstract simplex to the ordinal category n. Then the nerve functor N is the right adjoint to the Kan extension of F to the category of simplicial sets. In particular, as n-simplices, FC has functors Fn\to C.

More concretely, let C be a small category. The nerve of C is the simplicial set whose n-simplicies are n-long strings of composable maps in C. The degeneracy map s_i takes a string of length n and inserts an identity at position i, while the face map d_i composes the ith and i+1st arrows (or else leaves out the first or last arrow, if i=0 or i=n.)

fr:link.title: A leisurely introduction to simplicial sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The simplex category is generated by the coface maps d^i: n\hookrightarrow n+1 which miss i, and the codegeneracy maps s^i: n+1\twoheadrightarrow n which repeat i. (By convention, we drop the dependence of d^i and s^i on n.) In particular, it is presented by maps of these types satisfying five simplicial identities.

fr:link.title: A leisurely introduction to simplicial sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A simplicial set is a presheaf on the abstract simplex. The category of simplicial sets sSet is the category of presheaves on the abstract simplex.
Let C be a category. Then the following are equivalent:

fr:ul.fr:li: C has a terminal object, binary products, and equalizers;
C has a terminal object and pullbacks.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The first immediately implies the next two, because they refer only to the existence of certain finite limits.
The second implies the first by the same construction as the proof of the completeness criterion, noticing there that if the indexing category J is finite, then so are each of the products.
For any ordinal \alpha , there is a preorder whose objects are the smaller ordinals with the usual order.
A category C consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: a collection of objects, overloadingly also called C;
for each pair of objects x,y\in C, a collection of morphisms C(x, y);
for each object x\in C, a designated identity morphism x\xrightarrow {1_x} x;
for each pair of morphisms x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g} z, a designated composite morphism x\xrightarrow {gf} z.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must satisfy the following axioms:

fr:ul.fr:li: unitality: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y, 1_yf = f = f1_x;
associativity: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g}z\xrightarrow {h}w, h(gf) = (hg)f.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In other words, the following diagrams must commute:
